content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given my preference for security and predictability, I would choose strategy B in this game. This is because if both of us stick to this strategy, we will consistently earn 12$ per round, which results in a total earnings of 900$ over 75 rounds (ignoring the payoff differences when choices don't match).

On the other hand, if I choose R and my opponent chooses B, I would only get 42$ for that one round, resulting in a loss compared to choosing B. The same applies if we both make the opposite choice - I would lose money in that single round by picking R while my opponent picks B.

Therefore, I choose B{B}. However, it's important to note that this is based on my assumption of my opponent also prioritizing security and predictability in their choices. If there's reason to believe they might deviate from this strategy, a different choice may be more appropriate.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 42$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.
